Another intriguing choice could be "Afterlife," a poignant exploration of family dynamics and loss, with a focus on understanding and connection. Enjoy your viewing!

Given that you mentioned a preference for docudramas and the keyword "weird," I'd like to recommend "The Girl on the Train" (2015). This thriller follows a woman who becomes entangled in a missing persons investigation after witnessing something shocking from her train. The film stars Emily Blunt, who delivers a captivating performance as the troubled protagonist.

If you're interested in exploring an unconventional take on the docudrama genre, "Mommie Dearest" (1981) might also appeal to you. This biographical film offers a dramatic portrayal of the abusive relationship between screen legend Joan Crawford and her adoptive daughter, Christina. Faye Dunaway delivers an Academy Award-nominated performance as Joan Crawford.
